para.paratext: O.C.G.A. § 24-8-801(d)(2)(B) excludes from hearsay a statement of which the party has manifested an adoption or belief in its truth, which is identical to Fed. R. Evid. 801(d)(2)(B). Accordingly, Georgia courts will interpret this statute in accordance with federal case law, which provides that adoptive admissions include admissions by silence or acquiescence. As part of the enactment of this statute, Georgia repealed former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-36, which provided that acquiescence or silence could be construed as an admission.

Evidence of custodial silence of an accused is generally not admissible in federal court;[1] however, other tacit admissions of an accused may be admitted if two criteria are met: (1) the circumstances are such that an innocent defendant would normally respond and (2) there are sufficient foundational facts from which the jury could infer that the defendant “heard, understood, and acquiesced in the statement.”[2]

In Howard v. State,[3] the Georgia Supreme Court held that, where an accused is in custody so that a Miranda warning would be required (and especially if a Miranda warning has been given), his silence can never amount to a tacit admission. The court took this rule further in Jarrett v. State[4] where the court expressly overruled those cases holding that it is “permissible for a witness to testify as to what he saw and heard while in the presence of the defendant even though the declarant is not present at trial and subject to cross-examination” and held that “a witness in a criminal trial may not testify as to a declarant's statements based on the acquiescence or silence of the accused.”[5]

The same rule that a failure to reply may be an admission applies also to written correspondence. In McQueen v. Minolta Business Solutions, Inc.,[6] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the failure of a manufacturer to respond to a customer's letter and deny that the product purchased was covered by the manufacturer's express or implied warranty did not amount to a tacit admission that the manufacturer's warranty was in effect.

One party cannot set up an admission simply by sending out some isolated letter on some point.[7] However, in Jerkins v. Jerkins,[8] the court found that a party's failure to respond to a final demand letter from an attorney could be construed as an acquiescence to the terms stated in the letter in which the letter contained a differing interpretation of a contract.

U.S. v. Jenkins, 779 F.2d 606, 612, 20 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 98 (11th Cir. 1986); U.S. v. Carter, 760 F.2d 1568, 1579, 18 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 108 (11th Cir. 1985) (rejected on other grounds by, U.S. v. Manganellis, 864 F.2d 528, 27 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1063 (7th Cir. 1988)).

See also Jenkins v. Anderson, 447 U.S. 231, 100 S. Ct. 2124, 65 L. Ed. 2d 86 (1980) (holding that evidence of pre-arrest silence is admissible in absence of governmental action which may have induced the accused to remain silent).
Howard v. State, 237 Ga. 471, 228 S.E.2d 860 (1976). State v. Hill, 178 Ga. App. 669, 344 S.E.2d 491 (1986), followed Howard v. State. See also Hall v. State, 138 Ga. App. 20, 225 S.E.2d 705 (1976).
Jarrett v. State, 265 Ga. 28, 453 S.E.2d 461 (1995), overruling Reeves v. State, 194 Ga. App. 539, 391 S.E.2d 35 (1990), and Broome v. State, 141 Ga. App. 538, 233 S.E.2d 883 (1977).
McQueen v. Minolta Business Solutions, Inc., 275 Ga. App. 297, 620 S.E.2d 391 (2005).
Smith v. Freeport Kaolin Co., 687 F. Supp. 1550 (M.D. Ga. 1988).
